Yesterday, the citizens OF New Orleans
were greeted with the rare and wonderful
spectacle of the ascent Of MIR, Robertson IN
to the regions OF tho upper air by the means
ot balloon. The crowd OF spectators was
immense, filling not oniy the enclosure in
which the preparations were made for the
Urlal vo} age, IN which there could not have
been less than 2,3UO persons, nut all the
neighborinS streets, the levee, the shipping,
and the tops Of houses, The day was fair,
the weather agreeable, though rather too
warm, the state OF the atmosphere too was
as favorable as could be wished, the wind
blowing moderate breeze to the eastward
of north. About II o'clock small circular
balloon was let off, which mounted almost
perpendicualiy, and then taking direction
before the wind, fell in the swamp apparent
ly four or FIVE miles below town. his was
followed successfully by two others, Gone o


which bore the shape of hsE,) both o


which went up III similar manner and de
scended in similar direction. A little af


ter one o'clock, the hour fixed, the hardy
nronaut mounted the Car, attached to The
great balloon, which lowered for two ol
three minutes over the heads of the specta


tors, while he saluted them OH every side.
and then majestica'ly mounted aloft, ht


waving Nag, on which were inscribed til,
names of Washington and Lafayette. A.


he rose high towards the clouds, tn,


sight was wonderful. glorious aud sub


lime beyond expression; he confined wavinl


his flag till his person was no longer visible
The ascent was almost perpendicular, til
the balloon attained its utmost height, ant


then it took direction about north euS,


gradually descending in place beyond tn


verge Of the cypress swamp. From the mo


memtnt when the balloon begun to ascend
it was visible about half an hour.


. Deep and intense anxiety was felt BY a,
classes and descriptions of persons for tb
J fate OF the intrepid man who had trusted hi
life to so rain an element in SO fragile
vehicle. Hour after hour passed away dur
ing which the streets were filled with pro
7 pie eagerly enquiring after news concernjn
him. Various runours were in circnlatior
n and many of ais friends began to fec! apnre
;, henson for his safety. About : o'clotI: ;

The United Eingdom of Great Britain and Ireland,
was concluded and signed at London, on the
thirteenth day of November, in the year Of our
Lord, one thousand eight hundred and twenty
six, which Convention Is, word Tor word, rs toll
lows:


Difficulties having arisen in the execution of
the Convention concluded at St. Petersburgh,
on the twelfth day of july 1922, under the me-
diation ofhis Majesty the Emperor OF all the Rus
sias, between the United States OF America, and
Great Britain, for the purpose OF carrying INTO
effect the decision of his imperial Majesty upon
The differences which had arisen between the
said United States and Great 'ritain, on the true
construction and meaning of the First Article OF
.he Treaty of Peace and Amity, concluded AZ
Ghcnt Oh the twenty fourth day OF December,
1914, the said United States and his Britanic Ma
esty, being eq,.ally desirous to obviate such
difficulties, have respectively named Picnpoten-
t,aries to treat and agree respecting the same,
that is to say;


The President of the United States of America
has appointed ALBERT GALItrIS, their Envoy
Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotcntiary to
his Brtanic Majesty


Andhis Majesty, the King Of the United King
dom of Great Britain and Ireland, the Right Hon
1rable WILLIAM IIusKIssoS, member OF his
said Majesty's most honorable priyy council, q
member CT Parliament, President Of the Commit
Tee UI frlNJ tOuUCll lot hHAIS VI IallG dllll
eign Plantations, and Treasurer OF his sand Ma
iesty's Navy, and HENRY UywIN AUnINGrON
Esquire, late his Majesty's Charge d'AtIalres (
,he United States of America


Who after having communicated 70 each 9th
r. the respective fun powers found 10 he IN du'
aud proper form, have agreed upon, and con
yluded the following Articles;


ARTICLE l.


His Majesty the King of the United Kingdom
of Great Braitan AMI Ireland agrees to pay, an
the United States Of America agree to receive
for tile use of the persons entitled to indemnihc.
ton and compensation By virtue OF the said dt
cision and Convention, the sum of twelve hui
tired and four thousand nine hundred and slXt
dollars current money Of the United states,
lieu of, and in full and complete satisfaction io
all sums claimed or clamabie from Great Britain
by any person or persons whatsoever, under til
said decision and Convention


ARTICLE H.


The object of the said Convention being TIN
fulfilled, that Conyentoni is hereby declared to !.
cancelled and annulled. save and except the S
Cond article Of the same, which has already bee
carried INTO execution by the Commissioners a
pointed under the said Conventions and save an
except so much of the Third Article Of tie san
as relates to the defntive list of claims, and h
already likewise been carrcd into execution /
luG SAID uCOfnlIll3siOnerS.


ARTICLE III


The said sum oftwelve hundred and four tho
sand nine hundred and sixty dollars shall be pa
at Washington to such person or persons As sh'
be duly authorized, on the part OF the Unit
States, to receive the same, in two equal pa
Inents, as follows:


The payment of the first half to be made tive
ty DAYS after official notification shall have be-
made, by the Government of the United State
10 his Brtanc Maiesty's Minister in the said
nited States, OF the ratification of the presc
Convention by the President Of the nit
States, by and with the advice and consent Of t

And the payment of the second half 70
made on the first day Of August, 1897,


Article ~


The above sums being taken as full and fiji
liquidation of all claims whatsoever arsln~
der the sad decision and Convention, both
final adjustment Of those claims, and the dis
button Of the sums so paid by Great Brit
to the United States shall be made in gu
manner as the United States alone shall Diet
mine; and the Government of Great Brit 81
have no further concern Or liability therein.


ARrIcLE v.


1t is agreed, that, from the date Of the
change of the ratfcations Of the present G
vention, the Joint Commission appointed
der the said Convention OF st. FetersbulBi,
the twelfth of July, 1922, shall be dissolved j

and papers in possession Of the SAID Comluiss
relating 10 claims under that Convention, S

shall be DULY authorized, on the part otthc
ed States, to receive the same. And the Bri

persons so authorized, all the documents
papers, Cor authenticated copies OF the sa
where the originals cannot conveniently be II
over,) relating to claims under the said Con-
ton, which he may have received from his
eminent for the use Of the said Commission,
formally to the stipulations contained in

ARTICLE vi.


The present Convention shall be ratified,
the ratiiications shall be exchanged in Londo
six months from this date, or sooner, if poss

From the Rallston Spa Ga-ctte,
THE NOTORIOUS JOE BErTlo

Picfg, n0raity. Gc.--Rcligion, to all class
cs of the community, is essential to the COM
fort and happiness of all, but it must be sup
ported from its intrinsic worth-from its in
herent and positive advantages. and not from
speculation or worldly profit. We are con
stantIy at war with those who make religion
trade. On Saturday man was placed at
the Bar to receive sentence for cheating an
other out Of 500, by forging and altering
number on 4 lottery ticket. He was sahc'
tilted looking man; and the Recorder stated,
that several highly respectable residents mao
pctitioned the court in his behalf, insisting
that he was not proper subject tor diS-
graceful punishment inasmnch as ne was
piuus man, steady in his devotions, and con
stantly attending prayer meeting. Inc
court very properly differed with the petl-
TONERS, and considered from that very cause
his punishment should be made the HEAVIER
as an example to those who violated the
laws of God and man, while PROCESSING 70
obey and respect both. The punishment
however, was very light, as our Recorder
"speaks daggers, but uses none" IL is MS
uniform saying, when pronouncing sentence
"we could send you for seven years to thc
state prison, but think that the great enus
of public justice would be answered by con
filming you six months in the penitentary'
and such is the Judgment OF the court"


~. Y. Enquirer

PASSED AT THE SECOND SESSION OF


THE NINETEENTH CONGRESS.
LAWS OF TIE UNTCN.
BY AUTHORITY.

Dec, 25, 1771.


"a very odd event happened lately IN our
neighborhood, viz MIR. Zebulon Stanhope.
farmer, living about five miles n f by n
Of this township, having trained a couple Of
large bears to the plough and other services
clapped them before his sled last week.
with twenty chipples of wheat for the New
City. The animals drew extremely well
I for four miles and half; when the halter Of
the near bear giving away, the farmer set
about repairing it; but whilst he was thus
emploved the inhuman beast sezng him by
the right leg, tore it miseraby, and both
bears hauling at once, ran away with the
Sled. So that with the utmost difficulty he
got home in four hours on foot.


Messengers were dispatched to look for
the sled and cargo; and two days being spent
in fruitless search they were given up for
lost But on the third at noon, the noise OF
a carriage near the house was heard, and
yonng G lad Stanhope jumped up to see who
was coming; when-behold to his great as
constituent, it proved to be the bears draw
/, ing the sled into the barn, with no earthly
thing in it. except four large bears and three
cubs The lad, and two men that happen
ed to be in the house, ran nlmbly and shut
ting the door, with my long gun, shot them
all through crevlce."

Extract Of letter from Remington Vt. dated


Dec. 25, 1771.

1t is stated that the most disgraceful trans.
actions have taken place on the Jersey shore,
where the ship Lewis was wrecked few
days since. A large body of men assembled
and committed depretations upon the cargo
in plundcring every thing from the wreck
which came within their reach. Is it posi-
BILE that such state of things can exist in
L civilized country like this! 1t is the most
base kind of piracy thus to plumber a ship
which has bravcd the perils of the deep, and
in an unfortunate hour been driven ashore
bv an act OF providence beyond the control
OF man.

splendid military ball was given at Pen
sacola on the 22nd ultimo, in honour of the
birth day of Washington. The military Of
ficers at Cantonmcnt Clinch, and the naval
officers of the United States ship John Ad
ans, Of the schooner Grampus and Of the
Navy Yard were invited guests. Appro-
pirate salutes were fired by the u. S. ships
laying in the bay.

proclaimed his arrival in the city lie ma
landed in the swamp, near Madame CAT
court S plantation about miles from town
on the GENTLY road. in little more than ba,f
an hour after. He was found by some ne.
croes, above the middle in mud and water
and by them was safely brought to terra fir
ma. having met with no accident. and lie
balloon, with every thing appertaining to Il
was saved Mr. II. estimates the height ~


which he asccnded at about 5000 feet.

In New York, on Saturday, the court fin
ed Mr.. Barker $3.50 for an alleged libel on
Richard Baifeld. Esq. their clerk, and re-
quired him to give bail in the sum of 900
dollars against transgressions OF that nature
for two years. A strenuous but unsuccess-
full effort was made by council for delay
in the decision on various grounds.

The case of the u. States. Us. $50 chests
of Tea. Lippincott * Co. claimants, has been
decided by the Supreme Court OF the United
States--on appeal from the Circuit Court of
the United States for the Southern District
Of New York. Mr.. Justice Washington de.
livercd the opinion of the Court, affirming
the decree of the Circuit Court, by which
the said teas were ordered to be restored to
the claimants, Internationally.

The merit Of tllese appriate ana classical

Of Princeton, a lady Of superior literary &C
quiicments, ard refined TASTE. She was Ia
military called iie DNtchess, from her ele-
gance and dignity Of manners; was 9 Lost

SEC. 2. IND brit further enacted, hat thc
several sums hereby appropriated, shall be pa'a
out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise
appropriated Prorided, however, that no
money appropriated by this act shall be pad to
any person, for his compensation, who Is III Az
rears to the United States, until such person
shall have accounted and paid into the Treasury
all sums for which he may be liable Prowdea
also, that nothing in this section contained shall
be construed IN extend to balances arslnB
solely from the depreciation of Treasury notes.
received by such person TO be expended IN the
public service ; but in all cases where the pay
or salary of any person is withheld, in pursuance
of this act. it Shall be the duty of the accounting
officer If demanded by the party, his agent, oi
attorney, to report forthwith, to the agent ot the
Treasury Department, the balance due; and "
shall be the duty of the said agent, within sixty
davs thereafter, to order suit to be commenced
against such delinquent and his sureties.


Approved; March ,, 1927.

full articles.article:
Yesterday, the citizens OF New Orleans
were greeted with the rare and wonderful
spectacle of the ascent Of MIR, Robertson IN
to the regions OF tho upper air by the means
ot balloon. The crowd OF spectators was
immense, filling not oniy the enclosure in
which the preparations were made for the
Urlal vo} age, IN which there could not have
been less than 2,3UO persons, nut all the
neighborinS streets, the levee, the shipping,
and the tops Of houses, The day was fair,
the weather agreeable, though rather too
warm, the state OF the atmosphere too was
as favorable as could be wished, the wind
blowing moderate breeze to the eastward
of north. About II o'clock small circular
balloon was let off, which mounted almost
perpendicualiy, and then taking direction
before the wind, fell in the swamp apparent
ly four or FIVE miles below town. his was
followed successfully by two others, Gone o


which bore the shape of hsE,) both o


which went up III similar manner and de
scended in similar direction. A little af


ter one o'clock, the hour fixed, the hardy
nronaut mounted the Car, attached to The
great balloon, which lowered for two ol
three minutes over the heads of the specta


tors, while he saluted them OH every side.
and then majestica'ly mounted aloft, ht


waving Nag, on which were inscribed til,
names of Washington and Lafayette. A.


he rose high towards the clouds, tn,


sight was wonderful. glorious aud sub


lime beyond expression; he confined wavinl


his flag till his person was no longer visible
The ascent was almost perpendicular, til
the balloon attained its utmost height, ant


then it took direction about north euS,


gradually descending in place beyond tn


verge Of the cypress swamp. From the mo


memtnt when the balloon begun to ascend
it was visible about half an hour.


. Deep and intense anxiety was felt BY a,
classes and descriptions of persons for tb
J fate OF the intrepid man who had trusted hi
life to so rain an element in SO fragile
vehicle. Hour after hour passed away dur
ing which the streets were filled with pro
7 pie eagerly enquiring after news concernjn
him. Various runours were in circnlatior
n and many of ais friends began to fec! apnre
;, henson for his safety. About : o'clotI: ;
E tbs evening, sho4;s from iotsaDd yo;c.

had an opportunity Of cffecting any resistant
He was at his meal, with his pistols lying
on the table, and his rifle resting on MS
shoulder--he made an attemptto discharge
the latter, but not having taken the precau
tion to undo the dcer-skin cover that was u
ver the lock, did not succecd--he was 'heh
pinioncd so closely, that to resist was use
less, and to escape impossible. ana the NO
torious Bettys, cheated of all his threats,
and foed in his most particular resolution,
was Obliged to yield himself a tame and quiet
prisoner to the enterprise OF tuimer Cory,
and Perkins.


He asked leave tn smoke, which beng
granted, he took out his tobacco, and win It
something else which when uno5SciVeu, as
hc hoped, hc threw il into the fre, But Co
ry saw it, and Immediately snatchcd It out
with a handful of GOALS. 1t was small lead
en- box, about the eighth Of an inch IN thick
ness, and contained paper in Cypher,w which
they could not read, but was afterwards dis
covered to be a d,3ha,m hthe British Com
v,andey M New YORK. Aud also an order
for .ei0 sterling on the Mayor Of New York,
should the despatch be safely delvercd--
Betty begged leave to burn it. but was reius-
/ ed--he offered them hundred gulneas II he
might be allowed to burn it-BuT THEY RE-
/ FUSED.


\ He then said, ~ am a dead man" but con-
timed to intcrccte with them to allow him
To escape lie made the most liberal offers,
part Of which he had present means to
make good-BuT THEY REFUSED.


lie was then taken To Albany-tried, con-
victed, and executed rs spy and traitor to
his country And the only reward these
daring men received Tor this hazardous
achicyament ~as tic riAc and pistols of Bet
tvs


The conduct Of the cartors Of Andre was
no'le; but that ofth" captors of Bettys, was
both noble aud heroic. hnire was a gen


tlenan, and without the means of defence


Bcttvs was fuly armed and known to be a


despciado The capture of the former was


bv accidcn'--ot the latter, by enterprise and


design. Ihat of the former, was without


dAngt r--of the latter at the imminent peril


of life. NuIre was Il mare important, but


perhaps n1t 4 male dangerous enemy, than


r. Us s--l;pth tempted their captors with


all sedncing gold, and both were foiled-


And venerating, a. da the noble achieve
u;ont of p.ulding, y iI!iams and Van Vert


and beicying, A. 10 that their deeds form


aprond commentary on the honest stregtt


Of the American character, | cannot with


hold my appreciation of the sentiment c?:-
pre- d. as tu the conduCt OF Fulmer, Co


~ and pcrkns--and second it with all my


Leart."


The toast was then drank amidst thunder'


OF applause, and the day was passed withou


accident in tile cnjoymcut Of high and pat
= riotic feeling.

The New York Statesman publishes the
following as a story founded on fact, and sup
poses that it had given rise to the report
that Morgan, had been found alive IN lana
ia.


Mr.. Joseph Morgan, keeper Of the TX
change Coffee House in Hartford, man OF
property, and responsibility, and one OF the

was recently in Upper Canada on importanI

the by-standers instantly supposed that Nv

natLral that he would secret himself it their
suspicious should be made known to him
They therefore kept dark, till darkness ha,
overcome the day, and natures soft nurse
hat! visited the pillow of Mr. Morgan ara
rocked his senses into forget.uness. ~.
midnight. "that dread hour" they ushcre0
into his he'd chamber with suitable hum
ber OF the ministers Of justice, reused M"

coutre himself for a march to Sir PereBiihe
Maitland. who had enjoined upon them ths
delivery to him of the lost, but now restored
Morgan. 1t was ia vain that the unarnitI
prisoner protested that he was not tue .'H,

written no book OH masenrv--lul tht' ~

full articles.headline:
BY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED


STATES OF AMERICA.

=APROCLAMATION. A
full articles.article:
The United Eingdom of Great Britain and Ireland,
was concluded and signed at London, on the
thirteenth day of November, in the year Of our
Lord, one thousand eight hundred and twenty
six, which Convention Is, word Tor word, rs toll
lows:


Difficulties having arisen in the execution of
the Convention concluded at St. Petersburgh,
on the twelfth day of july 1922, under the me-
diation ofhis Majesty the Emperor OF all the Rus
sias, between the United States OF America, and
Great Britain, for the purpose OF carrying INTO
effect the decision of his imperial Majesty upon
The differences which had arisen between the
said United States and Great 'ritain, on the true
construction and meaning of the First Article OF
.he Treaty of Peace and Amity, concluded AZ
Ghcnt Oh the twenty fourth day OF December,
1914, the said United States and his Britanic Ma
esty, being eq,.ally desirous to obviate such
difficulties, have respectively named Picnpoten-
t,aries to treat and agree respecting the same,
that is to say;


The President of the United States of America
has appointed ALBERT GALItrIS, their Envoy
Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotcntiary to
his Brtanic Majesty


Andhis Majesty, the King Of the United King
dom of Great Britain and Ireland, the Right Hon
1rable WILLIAM IIusKIssoS, member OF his
said Majesty's most honorable priyy council, q
member CT Parliament, President Of the Commit
Tee UI frlNJ tOuUCll lot hHAIS VI IallG dllll
eign Plantations, and Treasurer OF his sand Ma
iesty's Navy, and HENRY UywIN AUnINGrON
Esquire, late his Majesty's Charge d'AtIalres (
,he United States of America


Who after having communicated 70 each 9th
r. the respective fun powers found 10 he IN du'
aud proper form, have agreed upon, and con
yluded the following Articles;


ARTICLE l.


His Majesty the King of the United Kingdom
of Great Braitan AMI Ireland agrees to pay, an
the United States Of America agree to receive
for tile use of the persons entitled to indemnihc.
ton and compensation By virtue OF the said dt
cision and Convention, the sum of twelve hui
tired and four thousand nine hundred and slXt
dollars current money Of the United states,
lieu of, and in full and complete satisfaction io
all sums claimed or clamabie from Great Britain
by any person or persons whatsoever, under til
said decision and Convention


ARTICLE H.


The object of the said Convention being TIN
fulfilled, that Conyentoni is hereby declared to !.
cancelled and annulled. save and except the S
Cond article Of the same, which has already bee
carried INTO execution by the Commissioners a
pointed under the said Conventions and save an
except so much of the Third Article Of tie san
as relates to the defntive list of claims, and h
already likewise been carrcd into execution /
luG SAID uCOfnlIll3siOnerS.


ARTICLE III


The said sum oftwelve hundred and four tho
sand nine hundred and sixty dollars shall be pa
at Washington to such person or persons As sh'
be duly authorized, on the part OF the Unit
States, to receive the same, in two equal pa
Inents, as follows:


The payment of the first half to be made tive
ty DAYS after official notification shall have be-
made, by the Government of the United State
10 his Brtanc Maiesty's Minister in the said
nited States, OF the ratification of the presc
Convention by the President Of the nit
States, by and with the advice and consent Of t
Senate thereof


And the payment of the second half 70
made on the first day Of August, 1897,


Article ~


The above sums being taken as full and fiji
liquidation of all claims whatsoever arsln~
der the sad decision and Convention, both
final adjustment Of those claims, and the dis
button Of the sums so paid by Great Brit
to the United States shall be made in gu
manner as the United States alone shall Diet
mine; and the Government of Great Brit 81
have no further concern Or liability therein.


ARrIcLE v.


1t is agreed, that, from the date Of the
change of the ratfcations Of the present G
vention, the Joint Commission appointed

The present Convention shall be ratified,

Picfg, n0raity. Gc.--Rcligion, to all class
cs of the community, is essential to the COM
fort and happiness of all, but it must be sup
ported from its intrinsic worth-from its in
herent and positive advantages. and not from
speculation or worldly profit. We are con
stantIy at war with those who make religion
trade. On Saturday man was placed at
the Bar to receive sentence for cheating an
other out Of 500, by forging and altering
number on 4 lottery ticket. He was sahc'
tilted looking man; and the Recorder stated,
that several highly respectable residents mao
pctitioned the court in his behalf, insisting
that he was not proper subject tor diS-
graceful punishment inasmnch as ne was
piuus man, steady in his devotions, and con
stantly attending prayer meeting. Inc
court very properly differed with the petl-
TONERS, and considered from that very cause
his punishment should be made the HEAVIER
as an example to those who violated the
laws of God and man, while PROCESSING 70
obey and respect both. The punishment
however, was very light, as our Recorder
"speaks daggers, but uses none" IL is MS
uniform saying, when pronouncing sentence
"we could send you for seven years to thc
state prison, but think that the great enus
of public justice would be answered by con
filming you six months in the penitentary'
and such is the Judgment OF the court"

full articles.headline:
Extract Of letter from Remington Vt. dated


Dec. 25, 1771.
full articles.article:
Dec, 25, 1771.


"a very odd event happened lately IN our
neighborhood, viz MIR. Zebulon Stanhope.
farmer, living about five miles n f by n
Of this township, having trained a couple Of
large bears to the plough and other services
clapped them before his sled last week.
with twenty chipples of wheat for the New
City. The animals drew extremely well
I for four miles and half; when the halter Of
the near bear giving away, the farmer set
about repairing it; but whilst he was thus
emploved the inhuman beast sezng him by
the right leg, tore it miseraby, and both
bears hauling at once, ran away with the
Sled. So that with the utmost difficulty he
got home in four hours on foot.


Messengers were dispatched to look for
the sled and cargo; and two days being spent
in fruitless search they were given up for
lost But on the third at noon, the noise OF
a carriage near the house was heard, and
yonng G lad Stanhope jumped up to see who
was coming; when-behold to his great as
constituent, it proved to be the bears draw
/, ing the sled into the barn, with no earthly
thing in it. except four large bears and three
cubs The lad, and two men that happen
ed to be in the house, ran nlmbly and shut
ting the door, with my long gun, shot them
all through crevlce."

1t is stated that the most disgraceful trans.
actions have taken place on the Jersey shore,
where the ship Lewis was wrecked few
days since. A large body of men assembled
and committed depretations upon the cargo
in plundcring every thing from the wreck
which came within their reach. Is it posi-
BILE that such state of things can exist in
L civilized country like this! 1t is the most
base kind of piracy thus to plumber a ship
which has bravcd the perils of the deep, and
in an unfortunate hour been driven ashore
bv an act OF providence beyond the control
OF man.

splendid military ball was given at Pen
sacola on the 22nd ultimo, in honour of the
birth day of Washington. The military Of
ficers at Cantonmcnt Clinch, and the naval
officers of the United States ship John Ad
ans, Of the schooner Grampus and Of the
Navy Yard were invited guests. Appro-
pirate salutes were fired by the u. S. ships
laying in the bay.

proclaimed his arrival in the city lie ma

court S plantation about miles from town
on the GENTLY road. in little more than ba,f
an hour after. He was found by some ne.
croes, above the middle in mud and water
and by them was safely brought to terra fir
ma. having met with no accident. and lie
balloon, with every thing appertaining to Il
was saved Mr. II. estimates the height ~


which he asccnded at about 5000 feet.

In New York, on Saturday, the court fin
ed Mr.. Barker $3.50 for an alleged libel on
Richard Baifeld. Esq. their clerk, and re-
quired him to give bail in the sum of 900
dollars against transgressions OF that nature
for two years. A strenuous but unsuccess-
full effort was made by council for delay
in the decision on various grounds.

The case of the u. States. Us. $50 chests
of Tea. Lippincott * Co. claimants, has been
decided by the Supreme Court OF the United
States--on appeal from the Circuit Court of
the United States for the Southern District
Of New York. Mr.. Justice Washington de.
livercd the opinion of the Court, affirming
the decree of the Circuit Court, by which
the said teas were ordered to be restored to
the claimants, Internationally.
